Journal.Title: Journal of renal nutrition : the official journal of the Council on Renal Nutrition of the National Kidney Foundation

Article.ArticleTitle: Antiproteinuria Effect of Calcitriol in Patients With Chronic Kidney Disease and Vitamin D Deficiency: A Randomized Controlled Study.

Abstract.AbstractText: Vitamin D has been demonstrated to lessen proteinuria severity in chronic kidney disease (CKD). Compared with healthy populations, patients with CKD may have lower serum levels of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (1,25-(OH)2 D) and 25-hydroxy vitamin D (25-(OH) D).Â We investigated the effect of Â oral low-dose active vitamin D (calcitriol at 0.25 Î¼g, 3 times weekly) on urinary protein excretion.

We conducted a nonblinded and non-placebo-controlled study. In total, 60 patients with CKD (average estimated glomerular filtration rate of >15Â mL/min) who received a stable dose of angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) were enrolled in this 24-week study. We randomlyÂ assigned these patients to the vitamin D group (oral calcitriol at 0.25 Î¼g 3 times weekly with an ACEI or ARB) or the control group (ACEI or ARB). Change in the urine protein/creatinine ratio (uPCR) was the primary endpoint in this study.

The mean baseline uPCRs of the 2 groups were comparable (1.84Â Â±Â 0.83Â g/g vs. 2.02Â Â±Â 0.97Â g/g, control vs. vitamin D group; PÂ =Â .46). After the 24-week treatment, the uPCRs were significantly lower than the baseline values in the vitamin D group (1.35Â Â±Â 0.64Â g/g; PÂ <Â .05) but not in the control group. The values of uPCR decreased significantly at 8, 16, and 24Â weeks (PÂ <Â .05 vs. baseline) in the vitamin D group. The values of uPCRs were significantly lower in the vitamin D group than in the control group at 8, 16, and 24Â weeks (PÂ <Â .05). A positive correlation was discovered between reduction in uPCRs at 24-weekÂ and baseline 25-(OH) D serum level in the vitamin D group (rÂ =Â 0.738, PÂ <Â .001).
Supplementary low-dose active vitamin D could reduce proteinuria in CKD patients with low serum 25-(OH) D levels.
